Triggering Event: At 7 pm, she returned home to an empty house. Her husband had left a note saying he'd be late again. She felt her stomach churn, a familiar dread creeping in. She walked into their bedroom, seeing his half of the bed still unmade from that morning. A lone sock lay on his pillow, mocking her with its emptiness.

Every day is just another pointless cycle, feeling like I'm drowning in nothingness. It's hard to focus when you're so miserable. He never understands how lonely it feels, how much I miss having someone by my side. The way he leaves without even a kiss makes me feel worthless. When will things get better? Is anyone really happy like this? I hate coming back to this cold, dark room. Our life together used to mean something, but now it's just a hollow reminder of what we've lost. I try to tell myself it doesn't matter, that maybe someday he'll change, but deep down I know he won't. We were meant to be together forever, not just a momentary distraction before moving on. I feel like I'm running out of time. Why does everything have to fall apart? This isn't fair; I deserve better than this. But do I really? Am I just settling because I don't want to face reality alone? Maybe if I pretend everything is okay, he'll come back sooner. That would make sense, wouldn’t it? If I ignore how unhappy I am, maybe he’ll realize his mistake soon enough. But until then, I’m trapped in this misery, losing myself with each passing day. What’s the point of

Triggering Event: After a long, exhausting 12-hour shift at the hospital, he finally arrives home to find his fridge empty except for an overripe banana and a lonely beer. His stomach growls audibly as he slams the door shut in frustration.
Generated Assessment: Oh, fuck! My stomach is growling so loudly that I can hear it screaming at me. It's like it's trying to tell me something - "Hey, where's the food? All day, I worked hard, took care of patients, and now they're just going to leave me hanging like this? It feels like my body is literally starving. I'm starting to feel dizzy. How am I supposed to keep working when I'm wasting away over here? I need to get my hands on some real food. This banana doesn't cut it. I can almost smell the aroma of freshly cooked steak... *sniff sniff* No, no, no. That's just my stomach's way of telling me it's been too long since dinner. And don't even get me started on the beer. What kind of sick asshole leaves a beer unopened? Who does that? Doesn't anyone know how much work goes into taking care of those people? It's like they think I'm made of money or something. I swear, sometimes I wish I had a dollar for every time someone left me to starve like

Triggering Event: She spots him at the gallery opening, his wife hanging off his arm like an ornament. The same man who once told her art was merely "splashes of paint." His eyes meet hers, a smug smile playing on his lips. She feels her lip curl in response.

She remembers how he once dismissed her own artwork as mere splashes of paint, but now he's rubbing it in her face by being all over the place. It makes her sick to think about how he treats people like they’re nothing compared to his precious art. And now he has the nerve to act like he owns the night, laughing and joking with his friends like he’s the king of everything. It's just so typical of him, always thinking he's better than everyone else. She hates how he looks down on others for having more modest tastes, acting like he’s somehow superior just because he hangs out with rich collectors. But deep down, she knows he’s just a shallow artist who doesn't care about anyone except himself. And now he gets to be part of this exclusive club where artists show off their work, pretending they're something special when really they’re just pretenders. It makes her want to scream whenever she sees him, especially since he thinks he’s so much smarter than everyone else. But what really gets under her skin is how he acts like he owns the whole scene. Triggering Event: At 8 AM, the store's automatic doors slide open for the day. A sudden gust of wind blows in, scattering flyers across the floor. The 66-year-old male retail worker freezes mid-step, his heart pounding like a kick drum. He hadn't expected any customers this early; the silence was his usual comfort. Now, it's just him and the fluttering papers, each one a potential trap he must navigate to avoid triggering an alarm. His breaths grow shallow as he carefully steps over them, his hands trembling slightly.
Generated Assessment: What is wrong with me?! I'm so fucking anxious today! It's been a while since I've had a panic attack, but now it feels like my mind has turned into a war zone. My body is a battlefield, and every step I take is a fight against the enemy that's taking over me. Why can't I just relax? Can't I enjoy the quiet morning without turning everything into a disaster?! Fuck, why am I so sensitive? I know I have anxiety, but it doesn’t feel right. Every little thing—like a paper blowing by, or the sound of footsteps outside—is enough to send my brain into chaos. It’s like I’m waiting for some catastrophic event to happen, no matter how small. And what if there isn’t even anything out there? What if I just imagined it all? My head is racing again, and I can feel my heart pounding. I try to breathe deeply, but it’s hard when you're convinced your life is falling apart. I want to tell myself to calm down, but who am I kidding? This is real, and it feels terrifying. If only I could stop these thoughts before they become a nightmare. This isn’t normal. I know I need to get control back, but it’s hard when every movement makes me think something terrible is about to happen. I hate feeling like this, trapped in a cycle of fear that won’t let go. It’s exhausting. But fuck, I don’t care. I

Triggering Event: An hour before class starts, she finds an unsigned note tucked into her desk drawer at school: "You've lost your touch. Students are falling behind."
Generated Assessment: A student who was struggling to keep up with coursework is seen as representative of all students. The implication that this one student has lost his touch suggests that many other students are also falling behind. This perception reinforces the notion that students are not adequately prepared for the demands of college-level work, further solidifying the idea that they have fallen behind academically.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

A regular customer, whom she'd known for years through her work at the local department store, walked past her checkout counter without making eye contact or greeting her as he usually did. He went straight to another cashier who had started recently. She felt a pang in her chest, her hands trembling slightly as she processed the next customer's items.

Or maybe he feels embarrassed about forgetting my name, which is weird since we've known each other for years. If he forgot, he must really dislike me now. This can't be happening again. I feel so stupid—maybe he actually hates me. I wish I could see into the future and know exactly how this interaction will play out. If I knew, I wouldn't have to worry about feeling so embarrassed right now. Why does he have to go to that new cashier instead of me? Does he think they're better than me? Triggering Event: He stumbled upon her art exhibit, hung in the same gallery that had rejected his work last month. Her vibrant paintings, so much like his old ones, filled the walls where his could have been. Bitter taste coated his tongue as he remembered her words, "I told you to keep trying." He hadn't known she meant to surpass him.
Generated Assessment: He shouldn't have let it get to him. His talent wasn't good enough for them to even consider displaying his work, but hers? It was like they wanted to make up for rejecting him. She's talented, I guess, but so what? That doesn't justify how shitty I feel. If I just worked harder, maybe I'd be able to beat her and show them I'm better than this loser who got rejected again. Fuck, why did I ever think I could compete with someone like her? It's not fair; she's basically stealing my ideas. Shouldn't they be giving me another chance instead of her? But no, instead, I'm stuck seeing my dreams fail right in front of me. Why can't they see how hard I've tried? Maybe if I just kept going, I wouldn't be this bitter now, but nope, I fucked up by letting her win. This is all her fault because she made it seem like she didn't care about my feelings. I don't deserve to lose like this. I'm an idiot for thinking otherwise.

Triggering Event: She woke up to find her studio, once vibrant with colors and life, now draped in shadows due to an unexpected power outage. Her latest canvas, a swirl of blues and purples she'd been painting in anticipation of her upcoming exhibition, was left unfinished under the gray light filtering through the window. She felt her heart sink as she realized she wouldn't be able to complete it today, another day lost in what felt like an endless streak of setbacks since her last show. The silence was deafening, echoing her own quiet despair.
Generated Assessment: She *should* have woken up before this moment, but instead, she found herself trapped within the same cycle of disappointment that had been plaguing her for months. It's as if the universe itself is conspiring against her, forcing her to endure one failure after another. Every time she thought she was making progress toward recovery, reality threw another obstacle in her path. What’s worse, each failure feels like a personal betrayal, leaving her questioning whether anyone truly cares about her well-being. This pattern has become all too familiar—a never-ending loop of self-doubt and frustration. Despite her efforts to break free from these negative thoughts, they continue to haunt her, eroding her confidence and sense of purpose. She feels like a prisoner of her own mind, unable to escape the darkness that surrounds her. Even when she tries to focus on the positive aspects of her life, the weight of her past mistakes hangs over her like a shadow, threatening to consume everything in its path. As she looks back at her art, once a source of solace and inspiration, now it serves only as a reminder of what could have been. Each uncompleted piece, each missed opportunity, and each failed relationship all blend together into a haunting melody that plays on repeat in her mind. It’s as if every step forward is met with two steps backward, and no matter how hard she tries, she can’t seem to catch up. Triggering Event: He paused at the mailbox, heart pounding. Among the bills and ads was a familiar handwriting. The divorce papers he'd signed months ago, returned unopened by his ex-wife. He'd hoped she'd find closure, but seeing her script again stirred a wave of remorse. He opened it anyway, finding a note tucked inside: "It's not too late to change things."

Triggering Event: He wandered into their old apartment, now rented to strangers. Rain streaked the windows where they'd once hung his paintings. He found himself tracing patterns in the condensation, seeing her face in every droplet's descent. The echo of laughter lingered, but it was hers alone, not the joyous symphony they'd created together. He sat on their—no, her—floor, surrounded by unpacked boxes and a silence that felt like an accusation. His melancholy deepened with each breath of air thickened by memories.
Generated Assessment: Fuck this shit. I'm done living like this. She never loved me anyway. I don't know why I even try. This is all I get for my efforts, nothing but pain and disappointment. I’m not good enough, she doesn’t care, and I’ll always be just another fuckup. Life isn’t fair; you have to deal with it whether you want to or not. It’s fucking up, no matter what you choose. And I chose her, so I lost everything. Now, I can’t blame myself for feeling worthless. Nothing ever goes right for me, and when it does, it’s just an illusion. I deserve all of this misery, and I won’t stop until I’ve broken myself completely.
